**Here is more info about SLS and the pH of hair:
What are SLS's? They are surfactants or surface active agents. 
What does that mean? Surfactants may act as detergents, wetting agents, emulsifiers, foaming agents, and dispersants. So basically, they are a necessity in order to make products that you use on your body, in your washing machine, in your dishwasher, in dish soap, etc.
Sodium Laureth Sulfate (SLS), sodium lauryl sulfate (SLES), and sodium lauryl sulfoacetate (SLSa) are ingredients that sound and look similar, but are completely different.
SLS: has a small molecular structure and therefore, penetrates the skin easily. SLS, as well as its close relative SLES, are esters of sulfuric acid. Both are known skin irritants. 
SLES: might be somewhat less irritating than SLS, it is unable to be metabolized by the liver, which means its effects are much more long lasting. These are generally used in dish detergent, laundry detergent, and other harsh detergents that are used on a day-to-day basis, and also on items not used on skin.
SLSa: is derived from coconut oils. SLSa is a safe, skin friendly cleanser that offers rich lather without the irritation potential of some of the other good foamers. Because the molecular size of this surfactant is large it doesn’t penetrate the skin or the mucous membranes, so it does not cause the skin irritation as other sulfates, making it an excellent choice for gentle cleansing products.
Why are SLS or SLES used? The simple answer is that they are cheap. In so many commercial formulations and ingredients, the bottom line is money. Commercial companies are in this to make money, which leaves the consumer with a cheap, well-disguised and well-advertised product. As a consumer you have a choice, and you came to the right place! Handmade goods by etsy artisians are truly superior. 

***As mentioned, this is not a bar of soap- it is what is called a syndet bar. Many people are selling soap and calling it shampoo- check listings carefully! The pH of body or facial soap is not good for hair. Shampoos are generally around pH 6.0, whereas soaps tend to the alkaline, over 8.0 (some soaps can be even pH 10). This means cold processed soaps are not pH balanced for our hair. After shampooing with products out of the right pH range, the cuticle of our hair doesn't lie down, and this can lead to abrasion between the hairs. This is a serious cause of mechanical hair damage, and once you have damage, it's hard to repair it, even with the most intense conditioners.

Soap isn’t as soluble in hard water as most surfactants. Soap molecules in hard water are converted by double decomposition to form insoluble non-foaming salts like lime, calcium, or magnesium salts of fatty acids. This isn't a big deal on your skin, but it can lead to build up on your hair, leaving it looking dull and feeling kinda crunchy. They won't foam well if there are metal ions in your water - and most water contains metal ions - and they won't foam well in the presence of sebum. Given these properties, soap isn't going to remove all the stuff you've put on your hair and you won't get a feeling of being clean (or, ironically, your hair might feel too squeaky clean, which isn't a good thing).

Sodium Lauryl Sulfoacetate (SLSA) is an excellent foaming, bubbling, and lathering surfactant. Because the molecular size of this surfactant is large it doesn't penetrate the skin, so it does not cause irritation.

Sodium Methyl Oleoyl Taurate (SMO Taurate) is mild to skin and hair, provides tons of lather in hard or soft water, gives a silky soft after-feel to skin and hair 


Cocamidopropyl Betaine is a mild, natural surfactant derived from coconut oil. It used to boost and stabilize foam and improve viscosity in shampoo 

Stearic Acid is a fatty acid derived from natural sources used to thicken and stabilize formulations. It will impart a soft feel to lotions and creams.

ewax is an emulsifier and thickener.

Cocoa Butter is recommended for treatment of chapped skin and lips, and as a daily moisturizer to prevent dry, itchy skin. It is great for trapping in moisture, it stays on the skin and acts as a barrier. 

Mango Butter is very creamy butter, less greasy than some other butters and very emollient.

Pink Himalayan Sea Salt, contains a full spectrum of 84 minerals and trace elements. It is an unrefined, unprocessed "raw"salt that's hand-mined.

Hydrolyzed Soy Protein offers a reduction in static buildup and flyaway, improved manageability after shampooing, is a shine enhancer, provides protective colloid functions coating skin and hair.

Panthenol builds a thin moisture film on the surface of hair and makes it shine without oil or greasiness. In addition, it can penetrate the cuticle of the hair and bring moisture into the cortex. It gives good manageability and pliability to hair. Provides shine. It’s strengthening properties are well-known and widely used. Also known for it's anti-inflammatory properties.

Dimethicone improves wet and dry combing, increases shine, improves hair feel (softness), reduces static charge, and works as a humidity resistor.

Vitamin E, nourishes, moisturizes and helps regenerate the skin.This vitamin oil helps improve elasticity and helps promote healing of damaged skin.

Fragrance and/or essential oils, make you smell yummy!

Colorant, so we can tell shampoo from conditioner. Blue for shampoo- it rhymes! 



Conditioner Bar:

Sweet Almond Oil is an excellent emollient and softener. It is lubricating, but not penetrating. Good for skin that is very dry or inflamed.Rich in essential fatty acids, vitamins A, B1, B2, B6, and E.
